resources.string: گروه طراحی و برنامه نویسی کدپیچ
این اپلیکیشن توسط شرکت بهسامان هوش افزار کوشا با همکاری دانشگاه علوم پزشکی کاشان طراحی شده است. امید است تا گامی شایسته در جهت کمک به جامعه ی سلامت برداشته شود.
Head CT appropriatness criteria application (HAC app)

string-array.name: ct
string-array.item: + 2. Abrupt onset of a neurologic deficit – including stroke and TIA
+ 4. Headache, indications for imaging MRI preferred [One of the following] ( except for D, J, and K which is CT preferred)
6. CNS infection (MRI without and with contrast) [(Both A and B for new infection) or C or D or E or F]
+ 9. Evaluation after intervention or surgery (CT should be performed for this indication if MRI is absolutely contraindicated)
+ 10. Suspected acoustic neuroma (schwannoma) or cerebellar pontine angle tumor [One of the following] (preferably MRI)
12. Evaluation of tinnitus (ringing, hissing, buzzing, roaring, clicking, or rough sounds heard by patient) (preferably MRI)
+ 13. Arnold-Chiari malformation(preferably MRI) [One of the following]
+ 20. Proptosis including thyroid eye disease and exophthalmos
+ 21. Visual field deficit(preferably MRI) [One of the following]
+ 24. Follow up proven subdural hematoma, epidural, subarachnoid, or intracerebral (parenchymal) hemorrhage
26. Papilledema or other signs of increased intracerebral pressure (preferably MRI)
+ 27. Acute, chronic or progressive mental status changes (preferably MRI)
+ 29. Bell’s palsy, with unusual presentation[One of the following] (preferably MRI)
30. Planning for stereotactic or gamma knife surgery- may be approved with MRI of the brain

string-array.name: ct_1
string-array.item: + A. Minor or mild acute closed head trauma without neurologic deficit adult
B. Mild or moderate acute closed head injury under age 2
C. Minor or acute closed head injury with focal neurologic deficit
D. Moderate or severe acute closed head trauma
E. Subacute or chronic closed head trauma with cognitive and/or neurologic deficit (MRI without contrast)
F. Suspected carotid or vertebral dissection (CTA or MRA of head and neck)
G. Penetrating injury, stable neurologically intact
I. Drug or alcohol intoxication and evaluation is suboptimal or inadequate

string-array.name: ct_1_8
string-array.item: 1. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
2. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
3. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
4. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
5. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
6. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
7. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
9. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
21. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus

string-array.name: ct_2
string-array.item: A. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
B. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
C. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
D. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
E. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
F. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
G. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
H. Dysphagia with no GI cause
I. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
N. New onset of severe headache
V. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus
Y. Slow response to verbal communication

string-array.name: ct_3
string-array.item: + B. Deteriorating clinical status with new or worsening neurologic findings
C. Repeat after recent hemorrhagic stroke

string-array.name: ct_3_2
string-array.item: 1. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
2. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
3. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
4. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
5. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
6. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
7. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
9. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
22. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus

string-array.name: ct_4
string-array.item: B. Worsened by Valsalva maneuver, coughing straining or postural changes
+ D. Suspected subarachnoid hemorrhage (CT in early phase) with one of the following .
E. Infection in an extracranial location
F. Change in mental status, personality, or level of consciousness
+ G. Suspected carotid or vertebral artery dissection or unilateral Horner’s syndrome (Headache may be unilateral) (CTA or MRA or MRI)of the following
H. Head pain that spreads into the lower neck and between the shoulders (may indicate meningeal irritation due to either infection or subarachnoid blood; it is not typical of a benign process)
I. Suspected subdural hematoma with history of major head trauma or minor head trauma in an individual on anticoagulants
+ M. Chronic daily headache – headache for 15 or more days a month for at least 3 months
O. Rapidly increasing frequency of headache
P. Personal history of cancer and new headache (MRI without and with contrast)

string-array.name: ct_4_4
string-array.item: 1. With sudden onset of severe, exertional, or “thunderclap” headache
2. Associated with nausea, vomiting, diplopia, seizure, mental status change, or
3. History of prior known (documented on CTA, MRA, or angiogram) aneurysm or AVM

string-array.name: ct_4_7
string-array.item: 4. Horner’s syndrome, miosis and ptosis (contraction of the iris, drooping eyelid) or
7. Rapid onset of headache with strenuous exercise or Valsalva maneuver

resources.string-array:
a. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
b. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
c. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk )
d. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
e. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
f. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
g. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
h. Dysphagia with no GI cause
i. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
j. Numbness, tingling, paresthesias
k. Decreased level of consciousness
l. Papilledema
m. Stiff neck
n. New onset of severe headache
o. Drowsiness
p. New onset of vomiting
q. Nystagmus
r. Cranial nerve palsy
s. Gait disturbance
t. Personality or behavioral changes
u. New seizure
v. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus
w. Agitation
x. Somnolence
y. Slow response to verbal communication
z. Sudden falls
aa. Balance problems

string-array.name: ct_4_13
string-array.item: 1. New neurologic deficit (See L1 above) (MRI without and with contrast)
2. Imaging is not medically necessary if there is a normal neurologic examination and no new features of the headache

string-array.name: ct_5
string-array.item: A. Refractory seizures in a candidate for surgery (only if MRI is contraindicated or not available)
B. New onset of seizures unrelated to trauma with drug use (only if MRI is contraindicated or not available)
C. New onset of seizures unrelated to trauma with alcohol use (only if MRI is contraindicated or not available)
D. New-onset seizure unrelated to trauma age 18-40 (only if MRI is contraindicated or not available; MRI without contrast)
E. New onset of seizure unrelated to trauma older than age 40 (only if MRI is contraindicated or not available; MRI without and with contrast)
F. New onset of seizures with focal neurologic deficit unrelated to trauma (MRI contraindicated or not available)
G. New onset of seizures older than 18 following acute trauma
H. New-onset seizure older than 18 post subacute or chronic trauma (only if MRI is contraindicated or not available; MRI without contrast)
I. Suspicion of migration anomalies or other morphologic brain abnormalities in children

string-array.name: ct_6
string-array.item: + D. Bickerstaff encephalitis – usually follows a viral illness [Both of the following]
+ E. Fisher syndrome [Both of the following]
F. Follow-up during and after completion of therapy to assess effectiveness

string-array.name: ct_6_2
string-array.item: 9. Recurrence of symptoms after antimicrobial therapy

string-array.name: ct_7
string-array.item: + A. Evaluation of known primary brain tumor
+ B. Evaluation for known or suspected brain metastases in patients with known extracranial malignancy (MRI without and with contrast)one of the following
+ C. Cranial nerve palsy (MRI without and with contrast)
+ D. Suspected brain tumor (MRI without and with contrast)

string-array.name: ct_7_1
string-array.item: + 1. New signs and symptoms or worsening neurological condition
+ 2. Interval re-evaluation of known brain tumor

string-array.name: ct_7_1_1
string-array.item: a. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
b. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
c. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
d. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
e. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
f. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
g. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
h. Dysphagia with no GI cause
i. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
n. New onset of severe headache
v. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus
y. Slow response to verbal communication

string-array.name: ct_7_1_2
string-array.item: + a. Anaplastic astrocytoma, anaplastic oligodendroglioma or glioblastoma multiforme or any high grade or aggressive primary brain tumor
+ b. Adult low-grade infiltrative supratentorial astrocytoma or oligodendroglioma
+ d. Adult medulloblastoma and supratentorial PNET
f. Other primary intracranial cancers may be imaged at completion of treatment and thereafter at 90 to 180 day intervals if clinically stable and then annually
+ g. New signs and symptoms or worsening neurological condition

string-array.name: ct_7_1_2_1
string-array.item: i. Re-image after surgery (complete or subtotal)
ii. Image 2-6 weeks after completion of radiation therapy
iv. Every 60-120 days for 2-3 years if asymptomatic and then less often
v. New signs and symptoms (See 1 above) regardless of date of last imaging

string-array.name: ct_7_1_2_2
string-array.item: i. MRI every 3-6 months for 5 years then annually

string-array.name: ct_7_1_2_3
string-array.item: ii. Every 3-4 months for a year then every 4-6 months for 2nd year then every 6-12 months

string-array.name: ct_7_1_2_4
string-array.item: ii. Every 3 months for 2 years then every 6 months for 3 years then annually

string-array.name: ct_7_1_2_5
string-array.item: i. If unresected or WHO Grade 1 (benign) or 2 (atypical), image at 3, 6, 12 months after diagnosis then every 6-12 months or 5 years then every 1-3 years
ii. WHO Grade 3 (malignant) image at least at 3, 6, 12 months and then every 6-12 months or 5 years and then every 1-3 years more frequent imaging may be required

string-array.name: ct_7_1_2_7
string-array.item: i. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
ii. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
iii. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
iv. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
v. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
vi. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
vii. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
viii. Dysphagia with no GI cause
ix. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
xiv. New onset of severe headache
xxii. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus
xxv. Slow response to verbal communication

string-array.name: ct_7_2
string-array.item: + 1. Routine initial staging for one of the following
+ 2. New neurological signs or symptoms with any known malignancy[One of the following]
3. Prior to prophylactic cranial irradiation for small cell lung cancer
+ 4. Follow-up known brain metastases during or after chemotherapy
+ 5. Follow-up known brain metastases after whole brain radiation therapy
+ 6. Follow-up known brain metastases after stereotactic or CyberKnife® radiation treatment
+ 7. Follow-up known brain metastases after surgery
8. Known brain metastasis with new or worsening symptoms as indicated in number VII. B. 2.

string-array.name: ct_7_2_1
string-array.item: b. Melanoma stage II or higher
d. Non-small cell lung cancer for stage IB and higher

string-array.name: ct_7_2_2
string-array.item: a. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
b. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
c. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
d. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
e. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
f. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
g. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
h. Dysphagia with no GI cause
i. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
n. New onset of severe headache
v. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus
y. Slow response to verbal communication

string-array.name: ct_7_2_4
string-array.item: a. Follow-up after intervention to establish a new baseline
b. Imaging (MRI without and with contrast, and CT should be done only if MRI is absolutely contraindicated or unavailable) every 3 months for 1 year after completion of therapy
c. After one year imaging is performed based on clinical signs and symptoms (See 2 above)
d. Melanoma stage IIB or higher annually

string-array.name: ct_7_2_5
string-array.item: a. Follow-up after intervention to establish a new baseline then every 6 weeks for 3 months and then
b. Imaging (preferably MRI) every 3 months for 1 year after completion of therapy
c. After one year imaging is performed based on clinical signs and symptoms
d. Melanoma stage IIB or higher annually

string-array.name: ct_7_2_6
string-array.item: a. Every 6 weeks x 2, then every 12 weeks x 2, then every 3-6 months if stable

string-array.name: ct_7_2_7
string-array.item: a. Follow up after intervention to establish a new baseline then every 6 weeks for 3 months and then
b. Imaging (preferably MRI) every 3 months for 1 year after completion of treatment
c. After one year imaging is performed based on clinical signs and symptoms
d. Melanoma stage IIB or higher annually

string-array.name: ct_7_3
string-array.item: 2. Weakness or paralysis of muscles of mastication
3. Sensory loss in the head and neck
4. Weakness or paralysis of facial expression
7. Weakness or paralysis of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
8. Weakness or paralysis of the trapezius
9. Weakness or paralysis of the tongue

string-array.name: ct_7_4_1
string-array.item: a. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
b. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
c. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
d. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
e. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
f. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
g. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
h. Dysphagia with no GI cause
i. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
n. New onset of severe headache
v. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus
y. Slow response to verbal communication

string-array.name: ct_8
string-array.item: + A. Elevated pituitary hormones including precocious puberty
+ C. Known pituitary tumor (adenoma, microadenoma, macroadenoma)

resources.string-array:
+ 1. Pituitary apoplexy
+ 2. Acquired hypopituitarism
+ 3. Gonadotropin deficiency or hypogonadism
4. TSH deficiency 0. 4 and low to low-normal T4 and T3
5. ACTH deficiency (Addison’s disease)
6. ADH deficiency (diabetes insipidus)
+ 7. Growth hormone deficiency
+ 8. Visual problems
a. Bitemporal visual field loss – loss of peripheral vision bilaterally
b. Optic atrophy
c. Drooping eyelid
d. Diabetes insipidusd. Diabetes insipidus

string-array.name: ct_8_2_2
string-array.item: h. Langerhans cell histiocytosis of the pituitary

string-array.name: ct_8_2_3_1_1
string-array.item: 03. History of undescended testicle or cryptorchidism
05. History of chemotherapy or radiation therapy

string-array.name: ct_8_2_3_1_2
string-array.item: 01. Low to normal free testosterone, LH and FSH (the laboratory values may be requested)

string-array.name: ct_8_2_7
string-array.item: + b. Children with no evidence of malignancy, Crohn’s disease, renal disease, hypothyroidism, or Turner’s syndrome, and one of the following

string-array.name: ct_8_2_7_1
string-array.item: i. History of radiation or surgery to the pituitary or hypothalamic region
ii. Decreased levels of 3 or more pituitary hormones (TSH, LH, FSH, ACTH, GHRH,ADH)
iii. Decreased levels of IGF-I (insulin-like growth factor I) based on laboratory normal range
+ iv. Insulin tolerance test (contraindicated in individuals with history of seizures or coronary artery disease)

string-array.name: ct_8_2_7_2
string-array.item: i. Bone age more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age
ii. History of surgery or radiation in the pituitary or hypothalamus regions
iii. Growth hormone levels below normal (≤10 ng/mL [micrograms/L]
iv. History of intrauterine growth retardation
+ vi. Children over the age of 1
vii. Neonate random growth hormone level 20 ng/mL [micrograms/L]

string-array.name: ct_8_2_7_2_6
string-array.item: 01. Insulin tolerance test positive with GH response ≤10 ng/mL [micrograms/L]

string-array.name: ct_8_3
string-array.item: 3. New signs or symptoms such as visual changes, new headache, new onset of vomiting, papilledema, drooping eyelid, optic atrophy
+ 4. Follow-up of asymptomatic nonfunctioning microadenoma 10mm in size
5. Follow-up of asymptomatic nonfunctioning macroadenoma 6 months after the initial diagnosis and then annually

string-array.name: ct_8_3_4
string-array.item: b. MRI every 1-2 years for 3 years and then less frequently as long as tumor does not increase in size

string-array.name: ct_9
string-array.item: + A. New or worsening neurologic condition

string-array.name: ct_9_1
string-array.item: 1. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
2. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
3. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
4. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
5. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
6. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
7. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
9. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
22. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus

string-array.name: ct_9_2
string-array.item: + 1. Stable with no change in neurologic findings

string-array.name: ct_10_1
string-array.item: 1. Asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss by audiometry

string-array.name: ct_11
string-array.item: + A. Suspected obstructive hydrocephalus [Clinical findings and supportive history]
C. Suspicion of VP (ventriculoperitoneal) shunt malfunction

string-array.name: ct_11_1_1
string-array.item: e. Gait disturbance or ataxia (People with ataxia experience a failure of muscle control in their arms and legs, resulting in a \n \tlack of balance and coordination or a disturbance of gait)

string-array.name: ct_11_2
string-array.item: 1. Gait disturbance (shuffling, magnetic, wide based, disequilibrium, and slow gait)

string-array.name: ct_13
string-array.item: J. Follow up known Chiari with new or changed symptoms

string-array.name: ct_16
string-array.item: A. Head circumference greater than 2 standard deviations average for age

string-array.name: ct_17
string-array.item: A. Head circumference smaller than 2 standard deviations average for age

string-array.name: ct_20
string-array.item: A. Orbital asymmetry in a child with visual loss
B. Adult with painful visual loss
C. Hyperthyroidism with visual loss or visual compromise (Graves’ disease)

string-array.name: ct_21
string-array.item: A. Bitemporal hemianopsia (loss of peripheral vision)
B. Homonymous hemianopsia (loss of vision in the nasal half of one eye and the outer half of the other eye)
D. Heteronymous hemianopsia (loss of vision in either the nasal half or the outer half of both eyes)

string-array.name: ct_22
string-array.item: + A. Suspected cholesteatoma and audiogram demonstrating conductive hearing loss (CT of the temporal bone) and one of the following
C. Total deafness, congenital hearing loss (CT of the temporal bone)
D. Preoperative planning for cochlear implant (CT of the temporal bone)
G. Sensorineural hearing loss on recent audiogram (MRI of the head without and with contrast)
H. Mixed conductive and sensorineural hearing loss on recent audiogram

string-array.name: ct_22_1
string-array.item: 3. Purulent drainage from the ear or mastoid area
4. Purulent drainage and granulation tissue in the ear

string-array.name: ct_22_2
string-array.item: 1. Must have audiogram documenting conductive hearing loss

string-array.name: ct_23
string-array.item: A. Episodic with or without associated hearing loss or tinnitus
B. Central vertigo with or without other symptoms (MRI of the brain without and with contrast)

string-array.name: ct_24
string-array.item: A. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
B. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
C. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
D. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
E. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia

H. Dysphagia with no GI cause
I. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
N. New onset of severe headache
V. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus
Y. Slow response to verbal communication
BB. Follow up within 36 hours of initial presentation if not performed previously
CC. Interval follow up with or without change in clinical signs or symptoms

string-array.name: ct_25
string-array.item: + B. Suspicion of acute subarachnoid hemorrhage

string-array.name: ct_25_1
string-array.item: 2. Altered level of consciousness or loss of consciousness
6. Coagulopathy previously diagnosed (or current treatment with heparin or Coumadin®)

string-array.name: ct_25_2
string-array.item: 7. Headache and first degree relative with aneurysm
8. Treated aneurysm and/or AVM with new headache or findings on neurologic examination

string-array.name: ct_25_3
string-array.item: 2. Known brain metastases with change in neurologic status
4. Follow-up within 36 hours of initial presentation if not performed previously
5. Interval follow-up with or without change in signs and symptoms

string-array.item: a. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
b. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body

string-array.name: ct_29
string-array.item: Bell’s palsy is the sudden onset of temporary facial paralysis which is the result of an insult to the 7th cranial nerve or the facial nerve. It usually presents as unilateral paralysis of the face including the eyelid and decreased tearing.
A. No improvement in facial paresis after one month
D. Weakness or sensory loss in an extremity

string-array.name: cta
string-array.item: + 6. Abrupt onset of a neurologic deficit – including stroke and TIA
+ 8. Suspected cerebral venous thrombosis [Both symptoms and risk factors](MRA, MRI)
9. Evaluation of tinnitus (ringing, hissing, buzzing, roaring, clicking, or rough sounds heard by patient)
+ 10. Vasculitis including temporal arteritis[Both of the following]
+ 11. Unilateral headache with suspicion of carotid or vertebral dissection or unilateral Horner’s syndrome (CTA or MRA or MRI)one of the following

string-array.name: cta_1
string-array.item: A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage by CT or lumbar puncture
B. Proven subarachnoid hemorrhage with negative angiogram requiring follow up imaging

string-array.name: cta_2
string-array.item: A. CT or MRI positive for intracerebral bleed or hemorrhage or hematoma

string-array.name: cta_4
string-array.item: + A. Screening study for cerebral aneurysm
+ C. Known cerebral aneurysm documented by CTA, MRA or angiography
H. Preoperative planning for cerebral aneurysm management (surgical or interventional)

string-array.name: cta_5
string-array.item: A. Asymptomatic patient with carotid stenosis of 60% or more by carotid duplex US
B. Symptomatic carotid stenosis with carotid duplex US showing 60% stenosis or
C. Carotid duplex US showing ulcerated plaque

string-array.name: cta_11

string-array.item: 1. SAH or intracerebral hematoma on prior imaging

string-array.name: cta_4_3
string-array.item: + 3. Interval evaluation for stability in an asymptomatic individual

string-array.name: cta_4_3_1
string-array.item: a. Shortly after an interventional procedure (i. e. , surgery or embolization)
c. Untreated, unruptured intracerebral aneurysms image at 6-12 month intervals

string-array.name: cta_4_3_2
string-array.item: a. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
b. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
c. Acute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
d. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation

y. Slow response to verbal communication

string-array.name: cta_4_3_3
string-array.item: a. Aneurysm 5mm or less annually for up to 5 years and then every other year or
b. Aneurysm more than 5 mm every 6 months for up to 5 years and then annually

string-array.name: cta_7_1
string-array.item: 1. Immediate follow-up after a therapeutic procedure (i. e. , surgery, embolization, radiosurgery)
2. Routine follow up after a therapeutic procedure

string-array.name: cta_7_1_3
string-array.item: a. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
b. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
c. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
d. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
e. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
f. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
g. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
h. Dysphagia with no GI cause
i. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
n. New onset of severe headache
v. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus
y. Slow response to verbal communication

string-array.name: cta_7_2
string-array.item: 4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage on recent CT or MRI of the brain
6. Intracerebral bleed or hematoma, or hemorrhage on prior CT or MRI of the brain

string-array.name: cta_7_2_3
string-array.item: a. Motor weakness affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
b. Decreased sensation affecting a limb, or one side of the face or body
c. Acute or subacute ataxia (unsteady and clumsy motion of the limbs or trunk)
d. Confusion including memory loss and disorientation
e. Impaired vision, including amaurosis fugax, visual field loss and diplopia
f. Aphasia (loss or impairment of the ability to produce or comprehend language due to brain damage)
g. Dysarthria (speech disorder resulting from neurological injury)
h. Dysphagia with no GI cause
i. Vertigo with either headache or nystagmus
n. New onset of severe headache
v. Hearing loss or new onset tinnitus
y. Slow response to verbal communication

string-array.name: cta_8_2
string-array.item: 5. Meningitis, sinusitis or middle ear infections
7. Ear, sinus, face, mouth or neck infection

string-array.name: cta_10_1
string-array.item: + 6. Autoimmune disease such as but not limited to

string-array.name: cta_10_1_6
string-array.item: c. Giant cell arteritis or temporal arteritis with temporal tenderness

string-array.name: ctlist
string-array.item: + Abrupt onset of a neurologic deficit (including stroke and TIA) [One of the following]
+ Acute, chronic or progressive mental status changes(MRI)
+ Bell’s palsy, with unusual presentation[One of the following]
+ CNS infection (MRI without and with contrast) [(Both A and B for new infection) or C or D or E or F]
+ Evaluation after intervention or surgery (CT should be performed for this indication if MRI is absolutely contraindicated) [One of the following]
+ Follow up proven hematoma, epidural, subarachnoid, or intracerebral (parenchymal) hemorrhage [One of the following]
+ Headache, indications for imaging (MRI except for D, J, and K) [One of the following]
Planning for stereotactic or gamma knife surgery- may be approved with MRI of the brain
Proptosis including thyroid eye disease and exophthalmos [One of the following]
+ Re-evaluation after stroke [One of the following]
+ Seizure (MRI with gadolinium) [One of the following]
+ Suspected acoustic neuroma (schwannoma) or cerebellar pontine angle tumor [One of the following]
+ Suspected intracranial hemorrhage[One of the following]
+ Suspected pituitary disease (microadenoma, macroadenoma) [One of the following]
+ Visual field deficit (MRI) [One of the following]

string-array.name: ctalist
string-array.item: + Abrupt onset of a neurologic deficit – including stroke and TIA[One of the following]
Evaluation of tinnitus (ringing, hissing, buzzing, roaring, clicking, or rough sounds heard by patient)
+ Pre-operative study, carotid endarterectomy planned[One of the following]
+ Suspected cerebral venous thrombosis[Both symptoms and risk factors](MRA, MRI)
+ Unilateral headache with suspicion of carotid or vertebral dissection or unilateral Horner’s syndrome
+ Vasculitis ( temporal arteritis)[Both of the following]
